A handy guide to exploring the moon's timing on this special day, Friday, October 10, 2025.
The moon's late rise on Karwa Chauth is no coincidence but a result of its celestial dance. Its timing is influenced by its orbit, position in the sky, and Earth's location.
Karwa Chauth occurs on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha). Since it's just four days after the full moon, the moon rises later in the evening.
The moon appears about 50 minutes later each day, so by the fourth day of waning, moonrise shifts well beyond its time on the full moon night.
Your exact spot on Earth—latitude and longitude—sets when the moon rises, causing city-to-city time differences.
